issues.title: Make an exception for mobile networks
issues.author: furry13

comments.author: buraglio
comments.body: I think we should not exempt mobile carriers. 7050 may need to exist for a long time even in enterprise cases, but we should make clear that the preferred method is 8781.

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
Apparently those networks do not use RAs to configure clients. So we can say that the recommendations in the draft do not apply to the networks which do not use SLAAC for client config.

Long-term solution might be going to 3GPP ;)

comments.author: buraglio
comments.body: Text added in adopted draft -00

issues.title: New terminology to replace "deprecation" term
issues.author: buraglio
issues.body: There are some requirements tied to the term "deprecation" that we may want to avoid. Perhaps a new title such as "Encourage use of pref64 over RFC7050/DNS64/DNS for IPv6-only prefix discovery" may assuage the formality.

comments.author: buraglio
comments.body: changed to "Preference of pref64 over DNS64 for Discovery of IPv6 Prefix Used for IPv6 Address Synthesis"

issues.title: One more reason to NOT use 7050
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: Multihoming with different prefixes - never going to work.

comments.author: mstojens
comments.body: Well isn't it obvious? You just limit the prefixes from a given query to use with the router that routed the DNS response ;) /s

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
> Well isn't it obvious? You just limit the prefixes from a given query to use with the router that routed the DNS response ;) /s

Are we going to call it 'rule 5.55'. Or, better, Rule 6.66 - or just mPVD ;)

On a serious note, thanks for reminding me that we have issues opened!! Let me add a section about that, before submitting..

issues.title: VPN DNS Override
issues.author: buraglio
issues.body: Certain VPN clients, particularly mesh VPNs, may impose DNS servers for use that prevent prefix discovery via RFC 7050. This problem is solved by using pref64 per RFC 8781, but may present issues on systems which only support RFC 7050.

issues.title: [WGLC] Dan Wing: discuss why DoH or DoT still doesn't make 7050 better than 8781
issues.author: mstojens

issues.title: [AD Review] Operational Considerations section
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From Med's email:

"there are deployment implications, e.g., on the number of network nodes that are required to be upgraded vs. one single touch as in 7050. This impact and, given that millions of devices are using 7050 today, I do think that we need to discuss the implications in a dedicated Operational Considerations sections."

issues.title: [AD Review] Difference in 7050 limitations for NSP vs WKP
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From Med's email:

"Some of the 7050 limitations are exacerbated when NSP used, but are less a concern when WKP. Not sure if you want to remind that in the document."

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
I assume this is for Section 3.1, Dependency on Network-provied resolvers. TBH I', not convinced it's the case. No matter what prefix is used - NSP or WKP - if the client is not using the network-provided resolver, it can not discover the prefix. 

I'll add a sentence that if a 3rd-oparty resolver used by the endpoint is also a DNS64 one, using the WKP, it would be just a coincidence that the client discovers the same prefix. However there is no guarantee that when the endoint moves to another network, that network provides NAT64 at all or if it does, the same prefix is used.

issues.title: [AD Review] Clarify 'mobile endpoints'
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From Med's email:

_"The document says that the recommendation does not target mobile networks, but uses mobile endpoints as an argument to motivate the need for dynamic discovery:

 

   Dynamic PREF64 discovery is often essential, particularly for

   unmanaged or mobile endpoints, where static configuration is

   impractical.

 

(I agree a mobile endpoint may not be connected to what is referred to as “mobile networks” in 4.1.1 but absent clarification this may be confusing and can be seen as internal inconsistency)"_

issues.title: [AD Review] Difference in recommendations between 8781 and this draft
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
From Med's email:

_"Please note that RFC8781 already includes a preference recommendation vs 7050; some text to position the new reco vs that one would be helpful"_

issues.title: [AD Review] Address comments from the detailed review
issues.author: furry13

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
Comments on comments I decided not to address so far:

1. I think most references for RFC7915 are correct, as the text talks about the translation, not matter stateless or stateful. 6146 defines stateful NAT64 while most of the text is also applicable to devices performing stateless translation as per RFC7915. The document has been updated to avoid using the term 'NAT64' when RFC7915 is mentioned.
2. Introduction: it was suggested to adde text about "support application referrals with IPv4 literals". I think we need more details/references to clarify the proposed text. It might be just my ignorance but I wasn't aware of that use case and when I googled 'applications referrals" and ip addresses I couldn't find anything related.
3. In Definition section, I'm not sure how to address a comment about 'generalized definition'.

To be continued..

issues.title: [AD Review] RFC9499 reference
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
Section 3.5.2 says:

"While they could, there have also since been multiple mechanisms defined for performing DNS-specific encryption such as those defined in [RFC9499] that would be more appropriately scoped to the applicable DNS traffic."

Med's comment: "I don't understand RFC9499 citation here"


Tommy, any suggestions on how to clarify the text?

comments.author: mstojens
comments.body: Sounds great -- your suggestions are appreciated and merged!

```suggestion
[RFC7050] describes a method for detecting the presence of DNS64 and for learning the IPv6 prefix used for protocol translation ([RFC6145]). This methodology depends on the existence of a well-known IPv4-only fully qualified domain name "ipv4only.arpa.". Because newer methods exist that lack the requirement of a higher level protocol, instead using existing operations in the form of native router advertisements, discovery of the IPv6 prefix used for protocol translation using [RFC7050] is deprecated to legacy status.
```

```suggestion
In addition to creating a wider attack surface for IPv6 deployments, [RFC7050]  has additional challenges worth noting to justify declaring it legacy.
```

reviews.author: furry13
reviews.body: LGTM , with some minor nits - when this gets merged, I'll add more text ;)

pulls.title: Adding more reasons to deprecate 7050
pulls.author: furry13
pulls.body:
- Additional reasons to deprecate:
- using 3rd-party resolevrs
- updating the PREF64 info
- delays

Also adding more text into the INtro, removing the citation in the Abstract and adding myself as a co-author

reviews.author: mstojens
reviews.body: whoops, introduced a new typo myself

comments.body:
```suggestion
[RFC7050] requires a node's communication channel with a DNS64 server to be a "secure channel" which it defines to mean "a communication channel a node has between itself and a DNS64 server protecting DNS protocol-related messages from interception and tampering." This need is redundant when another communication mechanism of IPv6-related configuration, specifically Router Advertisements, can already be defended against tampering by RA Guard [RFC6105]. Requiring nodes to implement two defense mechanisms when only one is necessary when [RFC8781] is used in place of [RFC7050] creates unnecessary risk.
```

reviews.author: buraglio
reviews.body: There was one conflict in the Recommendations for PREF64 Discovery which I think I resolved.

pulls.title: Change name, title, remove deprecate as a term, and minor spelling fixes
pulls.author: buraglio

comments.body:
Maybe we shall phrase it as 'discouraging using RFC7050' - that way it would be:
- more in scope of dnsops
- stay generic (in the unlikely event of a new NAT64 prefix detection method is invented, or people want to use PCP)

WDYT?

```suggestion
RFC7050 describes a method for detecting the presence of DNS64 and for learning the IPv6 prefix used for protocol translation (RFC6145). This methodology depends on the existence of a well-known IPv4-only fully qualified domain name "ipv4only.arpa.". Because newer methods exist that lack the requirement of a higher level protocol, instead using existing operations in the form of native router advertisements, discovery of the IPv6 prefix used for protocol translation using RFC7050 should be discouraged. RFC7050 MAY only be used if other methods (such as RFC8781]) can not be used.
```

pulls.title: Add a few acks, change reference to rfc7915
pulls.author: buraglio

pulls.title: Rename, create mobile section, other housekeeping tasks
pulls.author: buraglio
pulls.body: Rename to reflect v6ops, create mobile section to address last comment thread, add more acks, clean up a few typos and language.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Taking into account some fundamental flaws of the [RFC7050] mechanism, it is desirable to prefer [RFC8781] for all new deployments and for implementations to use consistent methods to obtain PREF64 information. RFC 7050 should be used only in cases where there is an inability to offer PREF64 information with a router advertisement, and as a fallback for legacy systems incapable of processing those RA options.
```

Shamelessly piggybacking minor grammar nits on your PR

```suggestion
Use of [RFC8781] may not be currently practical for networks that have more complex network control signaling or rely on slower network component upgrade cycles, such as mobile networks. These environments are encouraged to incorporate [RFC8781] when made practical by infrastructure upgrades or software stack feature additions.
```

The original phrasing did not make sense to me -- is this along the same meaning you intended? I also eliminated the use of a lower-case normative term; those always make me uncomfortable.
